ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: This course is designed for architecture students, and as an FES student, I felt that it didn't cover the subjects I was interested in as much I would have liked. I also felt that Professor Garvin sometimes was dismissive of questions (not many were asked in general, and when FES students asked questions, we tended not to get fully satisfying or even thoughtful responses). If you really want to work in local government or development and have NO experience in the field already, this can provide a decent way to get a run down of the issues. If you already have some exposure, however, and want to better understand the nitty gritty of how to leverage tax credits or historic zoning or create logical environmental regulations, you will be disappointed. Professor Garvin did a great job of presenting historical details about architects and specific development projects across America, but since this was not what I was interested in (I can reference his book on my own time), the actual class presentations were not very engaging.
Professor is a bit rambling. The homework assignments ("games") are great, but don't really seem to match what we learn in class.

The class was very helpful in understanding the basic mechanics of development and many historical precedents. It's especially oriented toward financial profitability. Social and --importantly for me, environmental-- effects of city planning become peripheral, and all but neglected.
I am better equipped to answer GPSCY trivia questions about the history of commercial development in the United States.
Games; opportunity to work with students from other schools.
Understanding the proforma (financial "worksheet") behind the financing of any projects, as well as learning the history of important development projects and the reasons they failed or succeeded.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: As an FES course, this course *should* address, or at minimum be more responsive to, the challenging questions surrounding continuing development in an increasingly constrained natural landscape. Smart growth -- even if Garvin doesn't like it -- should have at least been defined. Topics like open space requirements, green building codes, and integrated land and transportation planning were completely neglected. As an FES course, it is thus sorely lacking. As an architecture class, maybe its fine, but it may be time to take if off the FES cross list.

The course would be much more useful if Garvin tied lectures to case studies. For example, talk about how a development really came into being, things that went right and wrong, real analysis of results, etc.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Both were positioned to work with architecture students.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I'm interested in urban revitalization and economic development, and this is one of the only planning classes offered at Yale.
I'm interested in city government and environmental management, and given how much this intersects with planning and development, I wish it fit much better than it did into my overall program.

Overview of planning and development; I had taken a class in planning a long time ago in college, and was hoping for more concrete examples and discussion. The games satisfied that, but the lectures did not.
As an architect, I will have to understand how projects are developed: the financial, political, and social interests that will make a project possible and successful.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: See above (15)
To help me, as a future architect and project manager,to better understand how projects are financed, and how to ensure their political, and social feasibility and success.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: No. See question 10 and 13
See above (15)
Just about.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: No
No, but I might take his class in the spring -- seems more useful, smaller.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Advantage: working with architecture students was interesting -- always good to see other perspectives.Disadvantage: as an FESer, you're always the outsider, and since you're not an architect, the bulk of the assignment (designing, plotting, mapping, etc) are not in your skill set. So, by default, you take the writing section of the assignment and hope that the rest turns out ok.

It was good to interact with architecture students, though many of them seemed to have foregone conclusions about non-architecture students and their non-helpfulness. I enjoyed surprising my group members with a background in design and an ability to use graphics programs.
It was necessary to work in groups to distribute the wok load for games. Each member brought their perspective to the group, so it was very helpful overall.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Unless this is really up your alley and you know nothing on the subject already, I don't recommend you take it. Buy Garvin's book if you're interested in case studies and redundant theories.
Games are good; lectures are the least useful. Probably a good way to get your foot in the planning and development door, meet others interested in the field, etc.
